abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the Human
            Resources Project is rated as satisfactory. The seven-year
            project achieved most of its targets and effectively
            contributed to strengthening the country's human
            capital base by expanding the availability of trained
            manpower, thus enhancing productivity and facilitating
            economic restructuring. However, there was a change in
            national leadership in 1994, immediately after project
            effectiveness. The new government decided not to commit to
            the policy development sub-component of the general
            education component of the project, scaling down the initial
            objectives of the project, and thus contributed to the
            implementation delay. The main lessons learned from this
            project include: 1) A strong institutional set-up is needed
            in complex projects. 2) Project design should be as thorough
            as possible and requires extensive consultation with the
            stakeholders. 3) Project design should be simplified. 4)
            Implementation management capacity needs to be strong over
            the entire project life. 5) Clarity of and expertise in
            project implementation procedures is required. 6) Clarity
            and relevance of performance indicators and implementation
            of an education information system are essential for
            monitoring and evaluation.

5079474.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objective of the project
            is to strengthen the country's human capital base by
            expanding the availability of trained manpower. The specific
            objectives are: (i) to strengthen the quality and efficiency
            of basic education, with a view to raising student
            achievement; (ii) to improve the effectiveness, efficiency
            and responsiveness of technical and vocational education and
            training (TVET); and (iii) to reinforce employment services
            and labor market information. To these ends, the project
            includes the following components: (a) the general education
            support component aims to reinforce the basic education
            foundation by improving the quality of services and raising
            internal efficiency. The project supports the expansion of
            innovative and cost effective instructional strategies such
            as multi-grade teaching and school-based training; (b) the
            TVET development component aims to increase the
            effectiveness of TVET programs through the provision of key
            inputs to the learning process and to raise efficiency
            through increased sharing of facilities, expanded use of
            program view/evaluation procedures, and introduction of user
            fees in post-secondary education. Responsiveness would be
            improved through the introduction of flexible curricula,
            enhanced capabilities to evaluate performance and to
            design/implement new programs, provision of incentives to
            post-secondary institutions to enter into training contracts
            with industry, and increased accountability of institutions.
